habitat_description:
Oceanodroma homochroa is found off the coast of California year-round (Briggs et al., 1987; Ainley et al., 1995). They are strongly pelagic, using terrestrial habitats solely for breeding (Briggs et al., 1987; Zeiner et al., 1990; Ainley, 1995). They nest on offshore islands and islets (James-Veitch, 1970; Zeiner et al., 1990; Carter et al., 1992; Ainley, 1995; Adams and Takekawa, 2008). Some researchers have posited that nesting may occur on the mainland as well (Brown et al., 2003), though surveys have found no evidence for mainland nesting (James-Veitch, 1970; Brown et al., 2003). Nesting sites are typically rock crevices within talus (Ainley et al., 1976; Zeiner et al., 1990; Sydeman, 1998; Brown et al., 2003), on cliffs (Carter et al., 1992; Adams and Takekawa, 2008), or in sea caves (Zeiner et al., 1990; Adams and Takekawa, 2008) or in burrows excavated by other species (James-Veitch, 1970). During breeding, the species is nocturnal (Carter et al., 1992; Sydeman et al., 1998; Brown et al., 2003).

Ashy storm-petrels forage at sea (Briggs et al., 1987; Zeiner et al., 1990; Adams and Takekawa, 2008; Carter et al., 2008).
